verses.verse: And the LORD said to Job:
(Job 13.3; 23.4; 31.35; 33.13) “Shall a faultfinder contend with the Almighty? (Traditional rendering of Heb Shaddai) Anyone who argues with God must respond.”
(Job’s Response to God) Then Job answered the LORD:
(Job 29.9; 42.6) “See, I am of small account; what shall I answer you? I lay my hand on my mouth.
(Job 9.3, 15) I have spoken once, and I will not answer, twice but will proceed no further.”
(God’s Challenge to Job) (Job 38.1) Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind:
(Job 38.3; 42.4) “Gird up your loins like a man; I will question you, and you declare to me.
(Isa 14.27; Rom 3.4) Will you even put me in the wrong? Will you condemn me that you may be justified?
(2 Chr 32.8; Job 37.5) Have you an arm like God, and can you thunder with a voice like his?
(Ps 93.1; 104.1) “Deck yourself with majesty and dignity; clothe yourself with glory and splendor.
(Isa 2.12; 42.25; Dan 4.37) Pour out the overflowings of your anger, and look on all who are proud and humble them.
(1 Sam 2.7; Job 36.20; Isa 13.11; 63.3) Look on all who are proud and bring them low; tread down the wicked where they stand.
Hide them all in the dust together; bind their faces in the world below. (Heb the hidden place)
(Ps 20.6; 60.5; 108.6) Then I will also acknowledge to you that your own right hand can give you victory.
(v 19) “Look at Behemoth, which I made just as I made you; it eats grass like an ox.
Its strength is in its loins and its power in the muscles of its belly.
It makes its tail stiff like a cedar; the sinews of its thighs are knit together.
Its bones are tubes of bronze, its limbs like bars of iron.
(v 15|JOB 40:15; Job 41.33) “It is the first of the great acts of God; only its Maker can approach it with the sword.
(Ps 104.26) For the mountains yield food for it where all the wild animals play.
Under the lotus plants it lies, in the covert of the reeds and in the marsh.
(Isa 44.1) The lotus trees cover it for shade; the willows of the wadi surround it.
Even if the river is turbulent, it is not frightened; it is confident though Jordan rushes against its mouth.
(Prov 1.17) Can one take it with hooks (Cn: Heb in his eyes) or pierce its nose with a snare?
